The new UI we're hoping to move to for the "Press enter to send" option (do be deployed here soon) has the following below the "Send" button:

Screen-Shot-2021-12-02-at-1.12.19-PM.png

The shortcuts in the ? menu are different:

Screen-Shot-2021-12-02-at-1.08.27-PM.png

In terms of what actually works (on my Mac):
1) Cmd + Enter, Ctrl + Enter, and Shift + Enter all insert a new line if "Press Enter to send" is enabled.
2) Cmd + Enter and Ctrl + Enter send the message if "Press Enter to send" is disabled. Shift + Enter still inserts a new line.

As I'm writing this, I realize that the nice thing about suggesting Shift-Enter for inserting a line break in ? is that it always works. On the other hand, in the switcher widget, it's good to have the text remain the same when you switch. So perhaps it's fine to suggest Shift for inserting line breaks in ?, while suggesting Ctrl in the switcher.

But we probably need to change the switcher widget text for Mac users.

1) I think we should be consistent about referring to Cmd, and not Ctrl, for Mac users. See also #20107.
2) I got a bit lost when trying to understand Enter vs. Return. Should we replace Enter with Return (like it says on the Mac keyboard) for Mac users in the new switcher, the way we do in the ? menu?
See #design > compose box formatting button for further background on the new widget (just test-deployed here).

The latest version of the compose box toggle looks like this on a Mac:
Screen-Shot-2021-12-02-at-3.40.22-PM.png

Hm. I'm not convinced by the use of the pointing arrows. I think most of that is because I don't read the affordance of it as a thing I can click (it just looks like documentation), so I don't think of the "switch"/:repeat: sense of it when I first see it, so it seems out of place.
One option would be to have the pointing arrows only appear on hover, to indicate that's a thing that happens on click?
I think there needs to be an affordance that will cause people to hover in the first place.
Hmm, yeah. We certainly have space to have a button element if we feel this exchange icon is too subtle.
Making the :repeat: more button-like would be one direction to go.
Yeah, I like that idea.
(I bet I'm missing a ton of context) I feel like a toggle would be more obvious.
@Ken Clary can you do a little screenshot of what you have in mind? I'm not sure how to make a clear toggle with the space available.

I'll probably need to think how I'd lay it out before I could mock something up.
trivial case: literally a left-right slide toggle in place of the arrows, where the side that's selected gets a higher contrast color or something
(in which case, the texts don't move around when the choice changes)

That would have the benefit of not causing the button to jump around as well. I was momentarily confused when I clicked it and some of the text seemed to change. I had to re-read what it said to understand why that was.

I'd be interested to see a toggle version of this.

Actually, after typing that, I realized that I don't understand how it would work. What would the text say, and what would one side or the other being selected mean?

well, I would expect one side of text to say "return to send, <> + return to add a new line" or whatever, and the other side to say the opposite.
I expect this to look janky (but then so does the current solution), but with the texts not changing/moving, and the toggle being a visual "left or right" switch, it might at least be more obvious what is going on.
(I think I will read through some older topics to figure out what the issue was with the old checkbox)

right now it's a little bit like line noise --- the icons used for Return and such look more like buttons than the arrows, and the result is something that doesn't clearly look like an interactive ui element.
(or perhaps it looks like a complex set of UI elements mixed with text)

Ah, I see, so the toggle approach would require two copies of the text. If we go that route, we should probably skip the new line explanation. So it would just be, e.g.:

Ctrl + Enter to send (o--) Enter to send

We could try that...
@Aman Agrawal (amanagr) do you want to give it a shot?
perhaps instructions for how to add a new line to a message would be in a tooltip, or just in an explainer in the settings page
Sure, I can try to implement.

Screenshot-2021-12-07-at-11.54.30-AM.png

Do we want it to look something like this?
(wanted to make sure before investing into polishing this)
We could also move this switch button to the tooltip which is displayed when user hovers on the send button. I am not sure about the keyboard accessibility of that solution, though.
Hm, this seems a bit hard to parse. I was imagining something like a simple toggle doodad between "Ctrl + Enter to send" and "Enter to send". Screen-Shot-2021-12-07-at-12.26.24-AM.png
(not sure if that'll turn out well)

Well, I will argue that the design I proposed has 3 advantages over a simple toggle button:

  • No repetition of to send text.
  • More clickable area.
  • Current setting is super apparent.
even with a toggle, I recommend the entire area (with double text label) is clickable

the version shown starts to resemble a tab switcher, which is another interesting idea. as shown, it is at least more obvious that it's an interactive UI element and I can easily predict what will happen when I click it.

Ken Clary said:

even with a toggle, I recommend the entire area (with double text label) is clickable

@Ken Clary You mean we should have ( Ctrl + enter to send ) Enter to send?
in that particular case I mean having the whole Ctrl + enter to send (o..) Enter to send thing clickable, in the classic "labels should extend the clickable ui" sense
I guess with your concept (which is potentially very neat), I'd include "to send" in each label like you have it right there
Okay.
Hmm, a problem with this toggler design direction is that we no longer communicate how to create a newline rather than sending.
The idea is to have that tooltip tell that to the user.
Also, having a long text at the bottom of compose is not growing well on me.

FWIW Slack has similarly long text at the bottom of the compose box; the main thing they do different from what we currently have deployed is that they have it hidden until you type your first character (and it's a bit smaller). That said, I'm not sure that the Slack design is actually good; to me this is just a sign that this is a somewhat tricky problem to solve.
Slack's hint is significantly smaller, and is not interactive.
A challenge with the tooltip design is that it's not clear the user has a reason to hovering over that content and reading the tooltip.
I'm pretty sure I've seen a lot of text boxes that just have the "send" hint without a newline hint.... I can try to pull up some examples.
Another direction we could go in is (1) Have the send hint only and (2) have gear menu popover rather than the exchange symbol.

We could do something like LinkedIn and hide the switcher under "...":

Screen-Shot-2021-12-07-at-9.59.55-AM.png
Yeah, maybe a \vdots would be the right menu icon for our current design patterns rather than a gear.
And then the popover you get from clicking that menu can have plenty of space to explain the options, including how to make a newline if you configure Enter to send immediately.

(I had a dream where I realized the whole interaction should be hidden behind a gear, because it's not something you need to change particularly often... which just means I was thinking about this problem right before bed, not that it was a brilliant epiphany. ;))
The down side of the "..." approach is that, in the case of LinkedIn, I only now realized that the "..." menu had anything to do with how you send.

Ok, so the concrete proposal for trying a menu option is:

1) The line below the Send button says either "Enter to send" or "Ctrl + Enter to send".
2) There is a \vdots menu to the right of that line.
3) The menu has two options, with radio buttons to select between them:
o Ctrl + Enter to send
Enter to add a new line
o Enter to send
Shift + Enter to add a new line

Bold might not be the right formatting, but the idea is that the first line of each option is more salient compared to the second line.
I think that's worth trying!

I think it's solve all the problems we're trying to solve here:

  • Avoiding having too much text/clutter in the base compose box.
  • Making it really clear what the current state/instructions are.
  • Providing discoverability for the modifier+Enter related commands. (Note that tab+enter, ctrl+enter also work, but we likely don't have space for that outside perhaps a ? hover icon).
  • Having a thing that's clearly meant to be clicked on for how to change the configuration.

Alya Abbott said:

(I had a dream where I realized the whole interaction should be hidden behind a gear, because it's not something you need to change particularly often... which just means I was thinking about this problem right before bed, not that it was a brilliant epiphany. :wink:)

I had similar dreams when I was working on recent topics. It felt so good working on it. Everyone had something to say for how it should look like. There was so much community feedback.
Screenshot-2021-12-09-at-10.09.36-AM.png
Thoughts on this design?
It looks like both radio buttons are selected, to me?
@Aman Agrawal (amanagr) that looks nice to me, aside from the small thing Alex noted.
The other thing I'm not really sure about is it's visually clear enough that the \vdots menu is associated with the text next to it.
If we can't make that work, I think replacing the icon approach with words, e.g. "to send. Change" link would likely work at the cost of more clutter.
Just a design. :smile: Haven't got to the logic part.

Tim Abbott said:

The other thing I'm not really sure about is it's visually clear enough that the \vdots menu is associated with the text next to it.

Yeah.
To revise my "Change" proposal, I think we want non-blue link styling so it doesn't jump out until you hover.

The other direction to try would be a different icon than \vdots; maybe a gear or something. An explanatory label of the current value of a setting followed by an \vdots icon is not a common UX pattern for a button that opens a popover to change that configuration.
One could also try fa-pencil.

Maybe a v button? I agree that \vdots is not intuitive, but it would be great if we could avoid having to spell it out. I think having a word there would make it harder to parse the "Enter to send" text.
angle down
change
Angle down icon looks good enough that we don't need to use Change (which looks good as well to me)?
pencil
chevron-down

Angle down looks best to me; I don't think it needs a period.
I agree that looks better than the pencil version; I think we can try merging + deploying that here and get broader feedback with it in-app.
Certainly a lot better than what we have in main now, and changing that to different iconography would be a 1-line change.
angle down and chevron down look best to me

We probably want to use the other style of tooltips; I'm guessing the tippy ones will be too intrusive.

I like "Change send shortcut". A few notes on why:

  • "Shortcut" is more correct than "key", since it could be "Ctrl+Enter", which is 2 keys.
  • Words like "Toggle" and "Switch" suggest that clicking the button will immediately change it, not display a menu.
  • "Configure" sounds more complicated than "Change".
minor quibble: the second line of each menu item (describing adding new lines) is too grey. it looks disable (and hard to read)
